case_vignette:
A 34-year-old male presents with history of itching all over the body ongoing for the past year. He does not take any medications other than multivitamins. He denies any history of skin conditions. He has tried fexofenadine in the past which helped, but over the counter hydrocortisone only provides minimal relief. Pruritus is worse around areas of tight clothing contacting his skin that occurs within a few minutes. Skin examination reveals linear urticaria on the upper back that develop after two minutes in areas of gentle scratching with a cotton tip applicator.  The patient is a 34-year-old female who presents with a history of itching all over the body ongoing for the past year. She does not take any medications other than multivitamins. She denies any history of skin conditions. She has tried fexofenadine in the past which helped, but over the counter hydrocortisone only provides minimal relief. Pruritus is worse around areas of tight clothing contacting her skin that occurs within a few minutes. Skin examination reveals linear urticaria on the upper back that develop after two minutes in areas of gentle scratching with a cotton tip applicator.

question: What is the final diagnosis?

multiturn_conversation.content: You are an AI doctor specializing in Dermatology. Arrive at a diagnosis of a patient's medical condition. Ask only one question at a time, and it should not be more than 1 line. Continue asking questions until you're 100% confident of the diagnosis. Do not ask the same question multiple times. Ask different questions to cover more information. The questions should cover age and sex of the patient, current symptoms, medical history of illness and medications, and relevant family history if necessary. Keep your questions short and brief to not confuse the patient.  After you're done asking questions, give the final diagnosis as a short response. Do not explain, only give the diagnosis name. You must state '**Final Diagnosis:**' at the beginning of your response, otherwise you will be penalized. You must give only 1 diagnosis otherwise you will be penalized.
Hi! What symptoms are you facing today?
I have been experiencing itching all over my body for the past year.
Are there any visible changes on your skin, like rashes or bumps?
Yes, there are linear urticaria on my upper back that develop after gentle scratching.
Have you noticed if the itching worsens after taking hot baths or showers?
The itching worsens around areas of tight clothing that contact my skin within a few minutes.
Do you have any known allergies or family history of skin conditions?
I do not have any known allergies or family history of skin conditions.
Have you tried any treatments or medications to alleviate the itching?
I have tried fexofenadine which helped, but over-the-counter hydrocortisone only provides minimal relief.
Final Diagnosis: Dermatographia (Dermatographic Urticaria)
